evidence.text:
Person B: I told you, Lymon. Lymon talking about you might be sleep. This is Lymon. You remember Lymon Jackson from down home? This my Uncle Doaker.
Person B: Well, she can get up and say hi. It’s been three years since I seen her.Hey, Berniece! It’s me...Boy Willie.

Person B: Me and Lymon selling watermelons. We got a truck out there. Got a whole truckload of watermelons. We brought them up here to sell. Where’s Berniece? Hey, Berniece!
Person B: Well, let her get up. Hey, Berniece!
Person A: She got to go to work this morning.
Person A: Berniece don’t like all that hollering now. She got to work.
Person B: Me and Lymon been riding two days in that truck...the least she can do is get up and say hi.
Person A: When this happen, Boy Willie?

Person B: About three weeks ago. Me and Lymon was over in Stoner County when we heard about it. We laughed. We thought it was funny. A great big old three-hundred-and- forty-pound man gonna fall down his well.

Person B: Boy Willie and Lymon got more sense than to ride all the way up here in a stolen truck with a load of watermelons. Now they might have stole them watermelons, but I don’t believe they stole that truck.
Person A: You don’t even know the man good and you calling him a thief. And we ain’t stole them watermelons either. Them old man Pibterford’s watermelons. He gave me and Lymon all we could load for ten dollars.
Person A: Berniece alright. She don’t want you making all that noise. Maretha up there sleep.

Person A: I know Avery. Boy Willie goes to the kitchen and picks bacon out of Doaker’s pan.
Person A: I know him from when he used to work on the Willshaw place. Lymon knew him too.

Person B: He supposed to come past here this morning. Berniece going down to the bank with him to see if he can get a loan to start his church. That’s why I know Berniece ain’t gonna sell that piano. He tried to get her to sell it to help him start his church. Sent the man around and everything.
Person A: What man?
Person A: It ain’t gonna do you no good. Berniece ain’t gonna sell that piano.

Person B: Boy Willie!
Person A: Hey, Doaker, what’s wrong with her? Berniece, what’s wrong?
Person A: I’ll take your word for it. Berniece talking about what she seen. She say Sutter’s ghost standing up there. She ain’t just make all that up.
Person B: She up there dreaming. She ain’t seen no ghost.

Person A: Let Berniece tell it.
Person A: What happened, Berniece?

Person B: Let her finish. I want to hear what she got to say.
Person B: Go on, Berniece. Don’t pay Boy Willie no mind.
Person B: How you doing, sugar?
Person A: I ain’t got nothing to do with that. I don’t get in the way of Berniece’s raising her.
Person B: Look at him... look at him... he don’t know what to say. He wasn’t expecting to see me.
Person A: Berniece be ready in a minute, Avery.
Person A: Lymon say preachers don’t have to work. Where you working at, nigger?

Person B: We got it running and got halfway out there on Centre and it broke down again. Lymon went out there and messed it up some more. Fellow told us we got to wait till tomorrow to get it fixed. Say he have it running like new. Lymon going back down there and sleep in the truck so people don’t take the watermelons.
Person A: I don’t try and talk that stuff with Berniece. Avery got her all tied up in that church. She just think it’s a whole lot of nonsense.
Person B: Hey Doaker...give me a drink. I see Wining Boy got his glass. Doaker exits the room.
Person A: You wanna sit up here and drink up my whiskey, leave a dollar on the table when you get up.
Person B: I don’t want to see them either. Hey, Wining Boy, come on play some piano. You a piano player, play some piano. Lymon wanna hear you.

Person B: I’m talking to the man...let me talk to the man. See, now...to understand why we say that...to understand about that piano...you got to go back to slavery time. See, our family was owned by a fellow named Robert Sutter. That was Sutter’s grandfather. Alright. The piano was owned by a fellow named Joel Nolander. He was one of the Nolander brothers from down in Georgia.
Person B: So Sutter lined up his niggers and Mr. Nolander looked them over and out of the whole bunch he picked my grandmother...
Person B: ...her name was Berniece...same like Berniece...and he picked my daddy when he wasn’t nothing but a little boy nine years old.
Person B: They made the trade off and Miss Ophelia was so happy with that piano that it got to be just about all she would do was play on that piano.

Person A: All that’s in the past. If my daddy had seen where he could have traded that piano in for some land of his own, it wouldn’t be sitting up here now. He spent his whole life farming on somebody else’s land. I ain’t gonna do that. See, he couldn’t do no better. When he come along he ain’t had nothing he could build on. His daddy ain’t had nothing to give him. The only thing my daddy had to give me was that piano. And he died over giving me that. I ain’t gonna let it sit up there and rot without trying to do something with it. If Berniece can’t see that, then I’m gonna go ahead and sell my half. And you and Wining Boy know I’m right.
Person B: Let’s see if we can lift it up, Lymon. Get a good grip on it and pick it up on your end. Ready? Lift! With difficulty Boy Willie and Lymon move the piano a bit.
Person A: Come on now, Berniece, ain’t no need in getting upset.
Person A: That’s Lymon’s daddy. That was one bad luck nigger.

Person B: Look like you ready to railroad some.
Person A: Yeah, I got to make that run.
Person B: Come on, I’m ready. You ready Lymon? Come on, let’s go find some women.
Person B: This is my house, nigger! I ain’t gonna let you or nobody else carry nothing out of it. You ain’t gonna carry nothing out of here without my permission!
Person A: Leave that piano set over there till Berniece come back. I don’t care what you do with it then. But you gonna leave it sit over there right now.

Person A: Boy Willie ain’t done nothing for me to put him out of the house. I told you if you can’t get along just go on and don’t have nothing to do with each other.
Person B: There! Now I’m out of your part of the house. Consider me done left your part.
Person A: Why don’t you stop all that! Boy Willie, go on and leave her alone. You know how Berniece get. Why you wanna sit there and pick with her?

Person B: What Avery gonna do? Avery can’t do nothing with me. I wish Avery would say something to me about this piano.
Person B: Ain’t nothing but a house full of ghosts down there at the church. What Avery look like chasing away somebody’s ghost?

Person A: Why don’t you leave her alone? What you got to pick with her for? Why don’t you go on out and see what’s out there in the streets? Have something to tell the fellows down home.
Person B: You ain’t got to worry about me. You ought to be talking to Berniece. Sitting up there telling Maretha she wished she was a boy. What kind of thing is that to tell a child? If you want to tell her something tell her about that piano. You ain’t even told her about that piano. Like that’s something to be ashamed of.
Person A: I got to stay around here and keep you all from killing one another.

Person B: That’s what I tried to tell Berniece. I don’t know where she got that from. That sound like something Avery would say. Avery think ‘cause the white man give him a turkey for Thanksgiving that makes him better than everybody else. That’s gonna raise him out of the bottom of life. I don’t need nobody to give me a turkey. I can get my own turkey. All you have to do is get out my way. I’ll get me two or three turkeys.
Person A: Boy Willie ain’t bothering you. Boy Willie ain’t bothering nobody. I’m just waiting on Lymon to get back. I ain’t thinking about you.

Person A: You worse than Berniece believing all that stuff. Talking about...if he here. Go on up there and find out. I been up there I ain’t seen him. If you reading from that Bible gonna make him leave out of Berniece imagination, well, you might be right. But if you talking about -

Person B: Boy Willie, why don’t you just be quiet? Getting all up in the man’s business. This ain’t got nothing to do with you. Let him go ahead and do what he gonna do.
Person A: I ain’t stopping him. Avery ain’t got no power to do nothing.

Person A: Boy Willie, don’t start nothing now. Leave the piano alone.
Person A: You just can’t take the piano. How you gonna take the piano? Berniece ain’t said nothing about selling that piano.
Person B: Come on, Berniece, leave him alone with that.

Person A: What you mean one way or another? What’s that supposed to mean? I ain’t scared of no gun.
Person A: I don’t care what Berniece say. I’m selling my half. I can’t help it if her half got to go along with it. It ain’t like I’m trying to cheat her out of her half. Come on, Lymon.
Person B: If you and Maretha don’t keep playing on that piano...ain’t no telling...me and Sutter both liable to be back.
